subject: Failing multiple times in one test
msgSnippet: ... a ... filling ... Hashtable? Tsk, tsk... why aren t you using Map instead? :) ... Sounds like a simple approach. That should work nicely. ... Silly
messageBody:
>I'm writing a test whose purpose is to make sure that a Hashtable contains
a
>certain set of keys. Basically, the test will make sure that someone
filling
>out a form on the web provides all the mandatory info

Hashtable? Tsk, tsk... why aren't you using Map instead? :)

>I was thinking of creating the hash table with every set of keys, then to
>remove one key each time to test all the keys and make sure that the
>processing fails for each mandatory key.

Sounds like a simple approach. That should work nicely.

>I'd like a way to make
>the test fail for every parameter that is missing and consider each of the
>iterations as one test.

Silly question: why? Does it matter whether one, two or ten parameters are
not handled correctly? I think it matters more whether they are all handled
correctly, or not.

Also, who cares how many tests there are? Do you? Your manager? I don't want
to get into the discussion again about counting tests, but I have never
really cared how many tests I have, as long as I'm happy with the quality of
the tests.

Since JUnit counts test methods by default, you'd need one method per
parameter. Do you really think that's a useful thing to do? I don't.

JBR.
